elements.content: A 5d–3d bimetallic compound was prepared by self-assembling [W(CN)8]3– and the MnIII Schiff bases. This neutral complex consists of cyanide-linked WVMnIII anionic chains and isolated MnIII Schiff base cations. We demonstrate that two types of relaxation processes are involved in the system; the low-T dynamics may come from magnetic domain dynamics and the high-T relaxation stems from the anionic chain, revealing single-chain magnet character.
elements.clean_text: A 5d-3d bimetallic compound was prepared by self-assembling [W(CN)8]3- and the MnIII Schiff bases. This neutral complex consists of cyanide-linked WVMnIII anionic chains and isolated MnIII Schiff base cations. We demonstrate that two types of relaxation processes are involved in the system; the low-T dynamics may come from magnetic domain dynamics and the high-T relaxation stems from the anionic chain, revealing single-chain magnet character.

elements.content: A 5d−3d bimetallic compound was prepared by self-assembling [W(CN)8]3− and the MnIII Schiff bases. This neutral complex consists of cyanide-linked WVMnIII anionic chains and isolated MnIII Schiff base cations. We demonstrate that two types of relaxation processes are involved in the system; the low-T dynamics may come from magnetic domain dynamics and the high-T relaxation stems from the anionic chain, revealing single-chain magnet character.
elements.clean_text: A 5d-3d bimetallic compound was prepared by self-assembling [W(CN)8]3- and the MnIII Schiff bases. This neutral complex consists of cyanide-linked WVMnIII anionic chains and isolated MnIII Schiff base cations. We demonstrate that two types of relaxation processes are involved in the system; the low-T dynamics may come from magnetic domain dynamics and the high-T relaxation stems from the anionic chain, revealing single-chain magnet character.

elements.content: Low-dimensional magnetic materials such as single-molecule magnets (SMMs) and single-chain magnets (SCMs) showing slow magnetic relaxation have been explored with great interest because they have unique potential applications for information storage devices. Recently, a new research challenge has arisen because multiple relaxation processes were observed in some SMMs and SCMs. For instance, lanthanide-based SMMs possessing a strong spin–orbital coupling under the crystal fields demonstrated two-step magnetic relaxation processes with high anisotropic barriers. Moreover, the 5f metal-containing single-ion magnet U(H2BPz2)3 [H2BPz2 = dihydrobis(pyrazolylborate)] displayed a secondary slow relaxation process under an external magnetic field. Even the one-dimensional (1D) oxamato-bridged heterobimetallic Cu–Co chain illustrated two relaxation regimes in different temperature regions. Furthermore, a smooth transition from SMM to SCM character upon an applied static field was found in a 1D coordination polymer dysprosium bis(nitronyl nitroxide) accounting for size effects on the dynamic behavior. Thus, such newly emerging phenomena regarding slow relaxation dynamics in SMMs and SCMs have been discovered in the past a few years, which would broaden the territory of molecular magnetism.
elements.clean_text: Low-dimensional magnetic materials such as single-molecule magnets (SMMs) and single-chain magnets (SCMs) showing slow magnetic relaxation have been explored with great interest because they have unique potential applications for information storage devices. Recently, a new research challenge has arisen because multiple relaxation processes were observed in some SMMs and SCMs. For instance, lanthanide-based SMMs possessing a strong spin-orbital coupling under the crystal fields demonstrated two-step magnetic relaxation processes with high anisotropic barriers. Moreover, the 5f metal-containing single-ion magnet U(H2BPz2)3 [H2BPz2 = dihydrobis(pyrazolylborate)] displayed a secondary slow relaxation process under an external magnetic field. Even the one-dimensional (1D) oxamato-bridged heterobimetallic Cu-Co chain illustrated two relaxation regimes in different temperature regions. Furthermore, a smooth transition from SMM to SCM character upon an applied static field was found in a 1D coordination polymer dysprosium bis(nitronyl nitroxide) accounting for size effects on the dynamic behavior. Thus, such newly emerging phenomena regarding slow relaxation dynamics in SMMs and SCMs have been discovered in the past a few years, which would broaden the territory of molecular magnetism.

elements.content: Here, we report the synthesis, crystal structure, and magnetic properties of 1D complex [Mn(L)W(CN)8][Mn(L)(H2O)2]2·MeCN·H2O [1·MeCN·H2O; H2L = N,N′-bis(2-hydroxynaphthalene-1-carbaldehydene)-1,3-diaminopropane] comprising both bimetallic WVMnIII anionic chains and two isolated MnIII cations. Notably, two types of relaxation processes, which probably originate from the SCM behavior of the linear chain and a long-range order at low temperatures, are perceivable in this complex.
elements.clean_text: Here, we report the synthesis, crystal structure, and magnetic properties of 1D complex [Mn(L)W(CN)8][Mn(L)(H2O)2]2⋅MeCN⋅H2O [1⋅MeCN⋅H2O; H2L = N,N'-bis(2-hydroxynaphthalene-1-carbaldehydene)-1,3-diaminopropane] comprising both bimetallic WVMnIII anionic chains and two isolated MnIII cations. Notably, two types of relaxation processes, which probably originate from the SCM behavior of the linear chain and a long-range order at low temperatures, are perceivable in this complex.

elements.content: Compound 1 was obtained by a stoichiometric reaction of Cs3[W(CN)8]·2H2O with the corresponding MnIII Schiff base in a mixed MeOH/MeCN/H2O solvent. In the IR spectra, the CN stretching peaks evident at 2160w and 2141w cm–1 for 1·MeCN·H2O are compared with that (2145w cm–1) for Cs3[W(CN)8]·2H2O. The peak shift toward higher frequencies can be assigned to the coordination of some CN ligands to nearby MnIII ions.
elements.clean_text: Compound 1 was obtained by a stoichiometric reaction of Cs3[W(CN)8]⋅2H2O with the corresponding MnIII Schiff base in a mixed MeOH/MeCN/H2O solvent. In the IR spectra, the CN stretching peaks evident at 2160w and 2141w cm-1 for 1⋅MeCN⋅H2O are compared with that (2145w cm-1) for Cs3[W(CN)8]⋅2H2O. The peak shift toward higher frequencies can be assigned to the coordination of some CN ligands to nearby MnIII ions.

elements.content: Figure depicts the crystal structure consisting of a 1D linear bimetallic chain with MnIIIWV repeating units linked by cyanide bridges and two crystallographically dissimilar MnIII Schiff bases (Mn2 and Mn3). The W–C bond lengths range from 2.142 to 2.181 Å, and the W–C–N angles are slightly away from linearity, with a maximum deviation of 4.2° from 180°. The geometry of the W1 ion surrounded by eight C atoms from the CN groups is determined as a distorted dodecahedron based on the continuous-shape-measure analysis (Table S1 in the , SI). The Mn1 ion is in a tetragonally elongated octahedral environment, and a typical Jahn–Teller distortion occurs as a result of the longer axial Mn–N bond distances [Mn1–N1 = 2.307(3) Å and Mn1b–N8 = 2.373(4) Å; b = x, 1.5 – y, −0.5 + z] than the averaged equatorial Mn1–N(O) distance of 1.92(5) Å. The Mn–N–C angles in the cyanide-bridging pathways, which are magnetically important, correspond to 166.2(3)° for Mn1–N1–C1 and 159.1(4)° for Mn1b–N8–C8. The W–Mn distances within a chain are almost identical, 5.579 Å for Mn1–W1 and 5.605 Å for Mn1–W1a (a = x, 1.5 – y, 0.5 + z). The Mn2 and Mn3 centers are encircled by N2O2 donors of the Schiff bases and two O atoms from end-capped water molecules. The axial Mn–O distances are larger than the equatorial ones, spanning from 2.229 to 2.284 Å. This structural feature evidence the occurrence of a Jahn–Teller effect. The intermetallic distances between Mn atoms in the monomers and magnetic ions in the chain are 9.933 Å for Mn2–W1 and 8.533 Å for Mn3–Mn1a. In the extended structural view (Figures S1–S4 in the ), the Mn monomers (Mn2 and Mn3) are well separated by the existence of 1D octacyanometalate-based WVMnIII linear chains.
elements.clean_text: Figure  depicts the crystal structure consisting of a 1D linear bimetallic chain with MnIIIWV repeating units linked by cyanide bridges and two crystallographically dissimilar MnIII Schiff bases (Mn2 and Mn3). The W-C bond lengths range from 2.142 to 2.181 Å, and the W-C-N angles are slightly away from linearity, with a maximum deviation of 4.2° from 180°. The geometry of the W1 ion surrounded by eight C atoms from the CN groups is determined as a distorted dodecahedron based on the continuous-shape-measure analysis (Table S1 in the , SI). The Mn1 ion is in a tetragonally elongated octahedral environment, and a typical Jahn-Teller distortion occurs as a result of the longer axial Mn-N bond distances [Mn1-N1 = 2.307(3) Å and Mn1b-N8 = 2.373(4) Å; b = x, 1.5 - y, -0.5 + z] than the averaged equatorial Mn1-N(O) distance of 1.92(5) Å. The Mn-N-C angles in the cyanide-bridging pathways, which are magnetically important, correspond to 166.2(3)° for Mn1-N1-C1 and 159.1(4)° for Mn1b-N8-C8. The W-Mn distances within a chain are almost identical, 5.579 Å for Mn1-W1 and 5.605 Å for Mn1-W1a (a = x, 1.5 - y, 0.5 + z). The Mn2 and Mn3 centers are encircled by N2O2 donors of the Schiff bases and two O atoms from end-capped water molecules. The axial Mn-O distances are larger than the equatorial ones, spanning from 2.229 to 2.284 Å. This structural feature evidence the occurrence of a Jahn-Teller effect. The intermetallic distances between Mn atoms in the monomers and magnetic ions in the chain are 9.933 Å for Mn2-W1 and 8.533 Å for Mn3-Mn1a. In the extended structural view (Figures S1-S4 in the ), the Mn monomers (Mn2 and Mn3) are well separated by the existence of 1D octacyanometalate-based WVMnIII linear chains.

elements.content: Molecular view of 1. Symmetry transformations used to generate equivalent atoms: a = x, 1.5 – y, 0.5 + z; b = x, 1.5 – y, −0.5 + z.
elements.clean_text: 1  Molecular view of 1. Symmetry transformations used to generate equivalent atoms: a = x, 1.5 - y, 0.5 + z; b = x, 1.5 - y, -0.5 + z.

elements.content: The thermal variation of the magnetic susceptibility data for 1·MeCN·H2O was recorded at 1000 G (Figure S5 in the ). The χm T value of 8.91 cm3 K mol–1 at 300 K, somewhat smaller than the spin-only value of 9.38 cm3 K mol–1 for three uncoupled MnIII ions (S Mn = 2) and one WV ion (S W = 1/2), decreases smoothly and then abruptly upon cooling. This behavior supports the presence of antiferromagnetic couplings among paramagnetic W and Mn centers. To probe the underlying magnetic exchange characteristics, the Seiden chain model (χchain) based on H = −2J∑ i (S W,i ·S Mn,i + S W,i ·S Mn,i+1) for the (2, 1/2) alternating spin-chain system was employed and two isolated paramagnetic MnIII subunits (2χMn) were also included in the fitting process. The overall equation of χm = χchain + 2χMn was utilized under consideration of the molecular field approximation (zj′) to fit the data at T > 7 K, and a best result gives parameters of g = 1.96, J = −5.1 cm–1, and zj′ = −0.10 cm–1. It is manifest that intrachain antiferromagnetic couplings (J < 0) are communicated between MnIII and WV spins through cyanides. To gain insight into the magnetic exchange mechanism, we carried out density functional theory calculations on the dodecahedral [W(CN)8]3– (Figure S6 in the ). From the results, the N ends of bridging CN ligands are positioned at A and B sites at the same time. The spin density of the W center can be delocalized over the N ends in a π type. The N pπ orbitals dominantly overlap with dπ magnetic orbitals of neighboring Mn ions, eventually leading to the apparent antiferromagnetic arrangements. The saturation magnetization per Mn3W in the M(H) data taken at 2 and 4 K (Figure S7 in the ) is equal to 9.03 Nβ, lower than the theoretical result of g(S Mn – S W + 2S Mn) = 11 Nβ, assuming g = 2. This disparity may be due to the intermolecular antiferromagnetic interactions and magnetic anisotropy of the system. The critical field of H C = 1000 G was determined by the peak in the derivative of magnetization at 2 K. This behavior complies with the χm(T) curves, where the cusp at 3 K is present below H C and absent above H C (Figure S8 in the ). This observation is diagnostic of a field-induced metamagnetic transition. In the zero-field-cooled and field-cooled magnetizations, there is an irreversibility, indicating the presence of a magnetic phase (Figure S9 in the ).
elements.clean_text: The thermal variation of the magnetic susceptibility data for 1⋅MeCN⋅H2O was recorded at 1000 G (Figure S5 in the ). The χm T value of 8.91 cm3 K mol-1 at 300 K, somewhat smaller than the spin-only value of 9.38 cm3 K mol-1 for three uncoupled MnIII ions (S Mn = 2) and one WV ion (S W = 1/2), decreases smoothly and then abruptly upon cooling. This behavior supports the presence of antiferromagnetic couplings among paramagnetic W and Mn centers. To probe the underlying magnetic exchange characteristics, the Seiden chain model (χchain) based on H = -2J∑ i (S W,i ⋅S Mn,i  + S W,i ⋅S Mn,i+1) for the (2, 1/2) alternating spin-chain system was employed and two isolated paramagnetic MnIII subunits (2χMn) were also included in the fitting process. The overall equation of χm = χchain + 2χMn was utilized under consideration of the molecular field approximation (zj') to fit the data at T > 7 K, and a best result gives parameters of g = 1.96, J = -5.1 cm-1, and zj' = -0.10 cm-1. It is manifest that intrachain antiferromagnetic couplings (J < 0) are communicated between MnIII and WV spins through cyanides. To gain insight into the magnetic exchange mechanism, we carried out density functional theory calculations on the dodecahedral [W(CN)8]3- (Figure S6 in the ). From the results, the N ends of bridging CN ligands are positioned at A and B sites at the same time. The spin density of the W center can be delocalized over the N ends in a π type. The N pπ orbitals dominantly overlap with dπ magnetic orbitals of neighboring Mn ions, eventually leading to the apparent antiferromagnetic arrangements. The saturation magnetization per Mn3W in the M(H) data taken at 2 and 4 K (Figure S7 in the ) is equal to 9.03 Nβ, lower than the theoretical result of g(S Mn - S W + 2S Mn) = 11 Nβ, assuming g = 2. This disparity may be due to the intermolecular antiferromagnetic interactions and magnetic anisotropy of the system. The critical field of H C = 1000 G was determined by the peak in the derivative of magnetization at 2 K. This behavior complies with the χm(T) curves, where the cusp at 3 K is present below H C and absent above H C (Figure S8 in the ). This observation is diagnostic of a field-induced metamagnetic transition. In the zero-field-cooled and field-cooled magnetizations, there is an irreversibility, indicating the presence of a magnetic phase (Figure S9 in the ).

elements.content: The spin dynamics was checked by measuring the alternating-current (ac) magnetic susceptibility of 1·MeCN·H2O at H dc = 0 G (where dc is direct current), H ac = 5 G, and several oscillating frequencies (f; Figures a and S10 in the ). A peak at T p = 2.3 K and a shoulder at ∼2.7 K are observed in the out-of-phase (χm″) plot at f = 500 Hz. The shoulder signal moves toward higher temperatures with increasing f, characteristic of slow magnetic relaxation, while the lower peak lingers around the same temperature, indicating the onset of a long-range ordering. The heat capacity measurement should be convincing evidence for low-temperature long-range order. In the Cole–Cole diagrams (Figures b and S11 in the ), there is the distinct onset of a faster relaxation (relaxation I) and a slower relaxation (relaxation II) in the low-T regime (T ≤ 2.8 K) as well as the single relaxation region (relaxation II) in the high-T regime (T ≥ 3.2 K). In the low-T region around T p, the faster relaxation may arise from the presence of isolated MnIII ions or a fast domain response due to the long-range order. Because SMM behavior was demonstrated only in some MnIII dimers (not monomers), it is probable that the latter is responsible for the relaxation.
elements.clean_text: The spin dynamics was checked by measuring the alternating-current (ac) magnetic susceptibility of 1⋅MeCN⋅H2O at H dc = 0 G (where dc is direct current), H ac = 5 G, and several oscillating frequencies (f; Figures a and S10 in the ). A peak at T p = 2.3 K and a shoulder at ~2.7 K are observed in the out-of-phase (χm") plot at f = 500 Hz. The shoulder signal moves toward higher temperatures with increasing f, characteristic of slow magnetic relaxation, while the lower peak lingers around the same temperature, indicating the onset of a long-range ordering. The heat capacity measurement should be convincing evidence for low-temperature long-range order. In the Cole-Cole diagrams (Figures b and S11 in the ), there is the distinct onset of a faster relaxation (relaxation I) and a slower relaxation (relaxation II) in the low-T regime (T ≤ 2.8 K) as well as the single relaxation region (relaxation II) in the high-T regime (T ≥ 3.2 K). In the low-T region around T p, the faster relaxation may arise from the presence of isolated MnIII ions or a fast domain response due to the long-range order. Because SMM behavior was demonstrated only in some MnIII dimers (not monomers), it is probable that the latter is responsible for the relaxation.

elements.content: (a) Temperature dependence of χm″ for 1·MeCN·H2O at zero dc field and an ac field of 5 G with the indicated frequencies. The lines are guides for the eye. (b) Cole–Cole plots for 1·MeCN·H2O. The solid lines represent the fit with the generalized Debye model.
elements.clean_text: 2  (a) Temperature dependence of χm" for 1⋅MeCN⋅H2O at zero dc field and an ac field of 5 G with the indicated frequencies. The lines are guides for the eye. (b) Cole-Cole plots for 1⋅MeCN⋅H2O. The solid lines represent the fit with the generalized Debye model.

elements.content: To analyze the relaxation process, it was fitted using the generalized Debye model, where α gauges the distribution width of single relaxation processes and lies between 0 and 1 (Table S2 in the ). The well-fitted small α value of less than 0.34 at the slow relaxation region indicates a distribution of relaxation times. The relaxation II can be attributed to the SCM dynamics of the WVMnIII skeleton because the anisotropic 1D magnetic trait is defined by the combination of not only the effect of single-ion anisotropy from the Jahn–Teller ion but also an intrachain magnetic coupling contribution. The peak shift in the ac signals was taken into account with a quantity of φ = ΔT p/[T pΔ(log f)]. The φ value amounts to 0.28, which is in the range of superparamagnets. Using the Arrhenius equation of τ = τ0 exp(Δτ/kT), where τ is equal to 1/2πf and Δτ is the activation energy, the best parameters of τ0 = 9.42 × 10–9 s and Δτ/k = 19.3 cm–1 are acquired (Figure S12 in the ). As expected from the Glauber model in a 1D anisotropic system, a linear fit in the ln(χm′T) versus 1/T plot affords Δξ = 1.1 cm–1 on the basis of the magnetic expression of χT ∝ exp(Δξ/kT) where Δξ is the energy barrier to create a domain wall in the chain (Figure S13 in the ). The maximum in the curve is relevant with finite-size effects owing to the presence of defects and intermolecular antiferromagnetic interactions. Similar examples containing the W–Mn chains were reported to show typical SCM character.
elements.clean_text: To analyze the relaxation process, it was fitted using the generalized Debye model, where α gauges the distribution width of single relaxation processes and lies between 0 and 1 (Table S2 in the ). The well-fitted small α value of less than 0.34 at the slow relaxation region indicates a distribution of relaxation times. The relaxation II can be attributed to the SCM dynamics of the WVMnIII skeleton because the anisotropic 1D magnetic trait is defined by the combination of not only the effect of single-ion anisotropy from the Jahn-Teller ion but also an intrachain magnetic coupling contribution. The peak shift in the ac signals was taken into account with a quantity of φ = ΔT p/[T pΔ(log f)]. The φ value amounts to 0.28, which is in the range of superparamagnets. Using the Arrhenius equation of τ = τ0 exp(Δτ/kT), where τ is equal to 1/2πf and Δτ is the activation energy, the best parameters of τ0 = 9.42 × 10-9 s and Δτ/k = 19.3 cm-1 are acquired (Figure S12 in the ). As expected from the Glauber model in a 1D anisotropic system, a linear fit in the ln(χm'T) versus 1/T plot affords Δξ = 1.1 cm-1 on the basis of the magnetic expression of χT ∝ exp(Δξ/kT) where Δξ is the energy barrier to create a domain wall in the chain (Figure S13 in the ). The maximum in the curve is relevant with finite-size effects owing to the presence of defects and intermolecular antiferromagnetic interactions. Similar examples containing the W-Mn chains were reported to show typical SCM character.

elements.content: To further examine the relaxation dynamics, we measured ac data with increasing magnetic field (Figures S14 and S15 in the ). The Cole–Cole plots at T = 2.0 K show that relaxation I is predominantly appreciable until H = 500 G and the tail of relaxation II appears at H = 800 G. At T = 2.4 K, both relaxations I and II are detectable and relaxation II is more evident at H = 800 G. When the temperature increases to T = 2.8 K, relaxation II is prevalent. Thus, the application of an external field affects the spin dynamics for relaxations I and II. At T = 3.2 K in the relaxation II region, the shape of the Cole–Cole plots remains semicircular until H = 800 G and then disappears, which contrasts with the low-T domains. The larger magnetic fields (H > 800 G) mostly suppress the slow relaxation processes in the wake of a field-induced magnetic ordering, as confirmed by the temperature dependence of ac susceptibilities at H = 3000 G (Figure S16 in the ) in which the peak position at 3.1 K is frequency-independent and attributed to an ordering temperature.
elements.clean_text: To further examine the relaxation dynamics, we measured ac data with increasing magnetic field (Figures S14 and S15 in the ). The Cole-Cole plots at T = 2.0 K show that relaxation I is predominantly appreciable until H = 500 G and the tail of relaxation II appears at H = 800 G. At T = 2.4 K, both relaxations I and II are detectable and relaxation II is more evident at H = 800 G. When the temperature increases to T = 2.8 K, relaxation II is prevalent. Thus, the application of an external field affects the spin dynamics for relaxations I and II. At T = 3.2 K in the relaxation II region, the shape of the Cole-Cole plots remains semicircular until H = 800 G and then disappears, which contrasts with the low-T domains. The larger magnetic fields (H > 800 G) mostly suppress the slow relaxation processes in the wake of a field-induced magnetic ordering, as confirmed by the temperature dependence of ac susceptibilities at H = 3000 G (Figure S16 in the ) in which the peak position at 3.1 K is frequency-independent and attributed to an ordering temperature.

elements.content: To understand the in-depth magnetic nature of 1, a dehydrated compound [Mn(L)W(CN)8][Mn(L)]2 (1a) was obtained by the procedure in which 1·MeCN·H2O was heated at 140 °C under N2 flow because solvent molecules were thermally decomposed at 130 °C (Figure S17 in the ). The Nujol IR data (Figure S18 in the ) disclose that water molecules are completely removed for 1a and powder X-ray diffraction data were obtained (Figure S19 in the ). The χm T(T) curve of 1a is quite different from that for 1·MeCN·H2O, which may originate from the pronounced magnetic couplings between WV and MnIII of the desolvated sample generated by the removal of solvent molecules (Figure S5 in the ). The field- and temperature-dependent curves for 1a indicate operation of antiferromagnetic interactions and no magnetic order (Figures S20 and 21 in the ). From the ac data with and without dc fields (Figures S22–24 in the ), the slow magnetic relaxation processes are largely quelled in 1a, which may be due to the structural variation and subsequent magnetic consequence caused by solvent removal.
elements.clean_text: To understand the in-depth magnetic nature of 1, a dehydrated compound [Mn(L)W(CN)8][Mn(L)]2 (1a) was obtained by the procedure in which 1⋅MeCN⋅H2O was heated at 140 °C under N2 flow because solvent molecules were thermally decomposed at 130 °C (Figure S17 in the ). The Nujol IR data (Figure S18 in the ) disclose that water molecules are completely removed for 1a and powder X-ray diffraction data were obtained (Figure S19 in the ). The χm T(T) curve of 1a is quite different from that for 1⋅MeCN⋅H2O, which may originate from the pronounced magnetic couplings between WV and MnIII of the desolvated sample generated by the removal of solvent molecules (Figure S5 in the ). The field- and temperature-dependent curves for 1a indicate operation of antiferromagnetic interactions and no magnetic order (Figures S20 and 21 in the ). From the ac data with and without dc fields (Figures S22-24 in the ), the slow magnetic relaxation processes are largely quelled in 1a, which may be due to the structural variation and subsequent magnetic consequence caused by solvent removal.

elements.content: In summary, we have prepared a new bimetallic 3d–5d compound 1 composed of the WVMnIII anionic chain and isolated MnIII cationic moieties. This material shows two types of relaxation domains associated with SCM character and long-range ordering.
elements.clean_text: In summary, we have prepared a new bimetallic 3d-5d compound 1 composed of the WVMnIII anionic chain and isolated MnIII cationic moieties. This material shows two types of relaxation domains associated with SCM character and long-range ordering.

X-ray crystallographic files in CIF format, detailed preparations, and additional structural and magnetic data. This material is available free of charge via the Internet at http://pubs.acs.org.

metadata.title:
Cyanide-Bridged WVMnIII Single-Chain
Magnet with Isolated MnIII Moieties Exhibiting Two Types
of Relaxation Dynamics
